text: <@U0YJUECE8> Yeah, couldn't workaround this, I though I'd be able to comment out this step and put pre-built binaries in the busybox folder. But it did not work out. Ended up configuring local environment for the build.
are there any chaincode examples which already have a GUI implemented?
<@U3ENCLLUA|sibelius> has joined the channel
<@U3BSMKS21> there are 3 examples on IBM-Blockchain github
<https://github.com/IBM-Blockchain/marbles>
<@U0KPFAZNF> no license on baseimage repo?
<@U2TD4Q7NW> oversight, it was split out from fabric.git some months back
consider it identical to fabric.git
<@U0KPFAZNF> that's what I thought, slapping apache2 on my poc. Going to see how much I can plow though today.
also no more rocksdb?
librocksdb.so is no longer needed in master
well the important quesition is, does the replacement compile any faster? :stuck_out_tongue:
hah, well the replacement is native golang
so, while I havent qualified it, i would guess its probably about as fast as using pre-compiled librocksdb without having an external dep
and certainly faster than needing to compile librocksdb :wink:
is there a reason we pull from google for go instead of installing golang-1.7 from the package manager?
other than unsupported platforms like arm or IBM Z or whatever potato chip someone is using.
1.7 wasn't available packaged at the time
If it is now, I am not against using it
ghaskins  let me push what I have now and talk it over with you real quick
<@U0KPFAZNF>  <https://github.com/jkilpatr/fabric-baseimage-2.0>

attachments.title: jkilpatr/fabric-baseimage-2.0
attachments.text: fabric-baseimage-2.0 - An Ansible based build process for Fabric base image with platform agnostic design

text: so the idea is we have a playbook, which calls roles, which each perform a specific section of the build process then overwrite the docker image "fabric-baseimage-in-progress" in the local docker repo
this makes the same sort of docker pipeline as before, but in a way where each part is clean and seperate

if you need some special arch or whatever you could create a role ibm-java and in that handle installing ibm java in the container, the only bit I haven't figured out is if you use the role ibm-java how do we not install java back in the install-deps phase without adding disto + platform conditionals, which mean N distros * P platforms number of combinations to handle.
i have submitted a patch to use go 1.7 in the travis ci, welcome for review: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3215/>
<@U0Z41KY5V> are we still using travis?
well, this is a good question, if not, i guess need to remove those travis config files instead. Any suggestion :slightly_smiling_face:
